newsitem.title: CAMBODIA: Cambodian PM calls for referendum on monarchy.
newsitem.headline: Cambodian PM calls for referendum on monarchy.

text.p: Cambodian co-Premier Norodom Ranariddh on Tuesday called for a referendum on the thorny question of whether to keep the country's popular monarchy.
Prince Ranariddh, son of King Norodom Sihanouk, said he had no immediate designs on the throne but that the Cambodian people should decide the issue.
The monarchy question has driven a wedge in Ranariddh's fragile coalition government with co-Premier Hun Sen, who has sought to curb the monarchy's political influence.
"We have to organise a referendum. We have to ask the people's will," he said, adding he believed there was broad support for the monarchy.
Hun Sen said in mid-March he would cancel general elections expected in November 1998 if the highly popular king abdicated to take part in politics.
Ranariddh's royalist FUNCINPEC party and Hun Sen's ex-communist Cambodian People's Party are expected to oppose each other in the next election.
Ranariddh, speaking in an interview with Reuters, said he wanted to concentrate on politics with a goal of becoming the sole prime minister after national polls.
"No one for the time being can really take care of (my) royalist FUNCINPEC party...," he said. "My objective is to be the next prime minister and the only prime minister."
The current uneasy coalition was formed after U.N.-sponsored elections in 1993.
Hun Sen has said he would ask Sihanouk to ban members of Cambodia's royal family from politics unless they renounced their royal titles, a proposal Ranariddh has called unconstitutional.

Ranariddh said he would ask Hun Sen to reconsider his position on the monarchy and said the most likely solution to their differences was a referendum after the wishes of the king, who recently advised the government to take up the problem.
